testimony.name: Daniel Cohen
key_points: Supports City of Yes because it would make housing more affordable by alleviating the city's housing shortage
Strongly in favor of repealing parking mandates, which is environmentally friendly and economically progressive
Argues that mandatory parking increases rents for all, including those who don't own cars
Supports legalizing SROs (Single Room Occupancy) as an affordable housing option
Has personal experience living in an SRO when unable to afford a full apartment
Hopes City of Yes passes in its full form without any modifications

quotes_indicating_discussion.text: The second part that I really like is legalizing SROs, and The reason I wanted to highlight this is because I myself have lived in in an SRO in the past when I couldn't afford a full apartment to myself because the SRO was more affordable.
quotes_indicating_discussion.reasoning: While the speaker doesn't explicitly mention 'residential conversions', they discuss legalizing SROs (Single Room Occupancy), which falls under the broader category of residential conversions. The proposal mentions allowing 'commercial buildings to convert to a wider range of housing types, like shared housing â€” where apartments share kitchens and other facilities', which aligns with the concept of SROs.

quotes_indicating_discussion.text: Legalizing SROs is a great way to add more housing that's affordable to people who let people who like myself in the past. Aren't wealthy enough to afford a full apartment to to themselves.
quotes_indicating_discussion.reasoning: This quote further emphasizes the speaker's support for legalizing SROs as an affordable housing option, which is related to the residential conversions element of the proposal.

quotes_indicating_discussion.text: The first is repeal and parking mandates. So so not only is this environmental for environmentally friendly, it's also economically progressive.
quotes_indicating_discussion.reasoning: This quote directly mentions repealing parking mandates, which is a key aspect of the Removing Parking Mandates element of the City of Yes For Housing Opportunity proposal.

quotes_indicating_discussion.text: Parking spots don't get billed for free. So when we force developers to build parking, they pass on the costs in the form of higher rents.
quotes_indicating_discussion.reasoning: This quote discusses the economic impact of mandatory parking, which aligns with the proposal's argument that mandating parking drives up rent.

quotes_indicating_discussion.text: Rechealing park park mandates is a great way to be economically progressive.
quotes_indicating_discussion.reasoning: This quote reiterates the speaker's support for removing parking mandates, connecting it to economic progressiveness, which is in line with the proposal's goals.
